review.title: Combining Fuzzy Cognitive Maps and Discrete Random Variables
review.abstract: In this paper we propose an extension to the Fuzzy Cognitive Maps (FCMs) that aims at aggregating a number of reasoning tasks into a one parallel run. The described approach consists in replacing real-valued activation levels of concepts (and further influence weights) by random variables. Such extension, followed by the implemented software tool, allows for determining ranges reached by concept activation levels, sensitivity analysis as well as statistical analysis of multiple reasoning results. We replace multiplication and addition operators appearing in the FCM state equation by appropriate convolutions applicable for discrete random variables. To make the model computationally feasible, it is further augmented with aggregation operations for discrete random variables. We discuss four implemented aggregators, as well as we report results of preliminary tests.

sections.text: They use a simple representation of knowledge in the form of a directed graph, in which vertexes are interpreted as concepts and edges typically attributed by experts as causal relationships. FCMs, however, exhibit some similarity to neural networks based on structural properties and reasoning techniques. However, they are considered a semantic modeling tool: concepts typically identified by experts occur in the problem domain and weights that specify influences based on expert knowledge or data used in the learning process. Below, we present a brief theoretical introduction to FCMs.Let C = {c1,.,. cn} be a set of FCM concepts. A state of FCM is an n-dimensional vector of the conceptualization levels.

sections.heading: 2 Related works
sections.text: A large number of applications of FCM have been reported, e.g. in project risk modeling [9], crisis management and decision-making, in the development of economic systems and the introduction of new technologies [7], in traffic forecasting [10], in signal processing and decision support in medicine. Over the last 15 years, a number of FCM enhancements have been proposed. Fuzzy Grey cognitive maps use gray numbers (pairs defining interval limits) as a weight factor in the influence matrix.

sections.heading: 4 Aggregators
sections.text: For a discrete random variable X, its probability mass function pX: EX → [0, 1] is actually represented as a series of pairs: pX = {(x, p): x-EX-p [0, 1]. In our experiments, EX was finite and therefore limited: EX-X [xmin, xmax]. The basic idea behind at least three aggregators described in this section is to perform one-dimensional clustering. The values x-EX, which are close together, are grouped in clusters EX1,..., EXi,... EXk, and each cluster EXi is replaced by a single pair (vi, pi). The method for determining vi and pi depends on the algorithm, typically vi is determined by the type of averages in EXi and pi by summing probabilities.

sections.heading: 4.1 Simple k-means
sections.text: Simple k-mean is an adaptation of the well-known k-mean cluster algorithm [20]. The main difference is that initial centroids are not randomly selected, but are evenly distributed in the range [xmin, xmax]. For the resulting pV = {(vi, pi)} elements, vi are cluster centers and pi is a sum of probabilities assigned to the elements EXi = {xij} that form a cluster: pi = ∑ x EXi p (x). The method does not guarantee that the mean value of X is kept around V. Nevertheless, during the E (X) and E (V) experiments, a rather close connection was established.

sections.heading: 4.2 DBSCAN
sections.text: DBSCAN (Density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise) is a widely used cluster algorithm [20] characterized by low complexity O (n logn). It is controlled by two parameters - minimum distance between data points forming a neighborhood and λ - minimum cluster size. During the execution of algorithms, points whose neighborhood size is smaller than λ are discarded as outliers. On the other hand, neighborhoods with at least λ elements are converted into clusters and expanded further. Results of the algorithm, including the number of clusters, depend on established values of ε and λ.The aggregator discussed is based on the DBSCAN implementation in the JavaML library [1] with the following parameters: ε = xmax − xmink, where k is an upper limit for the number of resulting clusters and λ = 6. After executing the cluster algorithm, values belonging to the clusters (Xi) were converted to pairs (7).

sections.heading: 4.3 UniBins aggregator
sections.text: The UniBins aggregator divides the range [xmin, xmax] of an input variable X into k uniformly distributed containers, which are represented by the values v0,.., vn − 1. Container boundaries are blurred and a level at which an input element x can be assigned to a container is described quantitatively by the membership function of a container. This concept is illustrated in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 4.4 Percentile rank aggregator
sections.text: The percentile rank aggregator assigns the same probability ∆ p = 1 / k to each output value, while maintaining the percentile ranges of the input distribution. The assumed granulation level is ∆ p. The basic idea of the algorithm is shown in Fig. 2a. Let's analyze the order (xi, pi),... (xi + 3, pi + 3). As pi + pi + 1 + pi + 2 < p < pi + pi + 1 + pi + 2 + pi + 3, the value vk + 1 becomes between xi + 3 and xi + 4. The exact position depends on p − pi − pi + 1 − pi + 2, the smaller the distance between xi + 3 and vk + 1. Another characteristic of the percentile rank aggregator is its ability to generate multiple output values when the input ranges PMF changes quickly.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we discuss FCM4DRV, an extension of the classic FCM model, which consists of replacing concept activation levels with discrete random variables. The proposed model aims to define areas of activation levels achieved during FCM reasoning. We were motivated by a specific problem to select precise thresholds when analyzing IT security risk with FCM [19, 17, 18], but the solution presented here is more general and can be applied to a variety of problems. FCM4DRV extension includes extending the classic FCM state equation to include suitable operators applicable to DRVs, as well as introducing aggregators, special functions that transform DRVs into similar but less memory and require less computing.
